title: No attestations on Prater testnet
body:
### Description

Teku with initial state on Prater testnet does not attest. No indication in logs that it is even aware of its duties. Validator key is shown as loaded in logs.

### Versions (Add all that apply)
* Software version: `teku/v21.5.0/linux-x86_64/oracle_openjdk-java-15`

### Additional Information


This validator: https://prater.beaconcha.in/validator/0xa472cf65cd30b98234d9a1fcd6e50520f5c5d2e7d1b7e6beb1c7a0c064764d79b945e000b8a3d245cd0d87e1f3996e22#attestations

Was 10048 (0xa7c57a562ddd67f9d5f577254cfd6555f70e22df16a9b9d0b131b2ff543e0f10) but now 10049 (0x90b09bd4a285f79824b5987698764fbe47a960ca3d329c98cadcdb75b111544f)
```
consensus_1         | 11:33:13.049 INFO  - Sync Event  *** Current slot: 517666, Head slot: 321600, Connected peers: 20
consensus_1         | 11:33:25.180 INFO  - Sync Event  *** Current slot: 517667, Head slot: 321620, Connected peers: 22
consensus_1         | 11:33:36.898 INFO  - Sync Event  *** Current slot: 517668, Head slot: 321638, Connected peers: 28

consensus_1         | 11:34:13.070 INFO  - Sync Event  *** Current slot: 517671, Head slot: 321695, Connected peers: 27
```

After deleting chain DB and starting over, Teku logs that it attested, but actually did not. Watching for another epoch.

The epoch after that, Teku correctly attested.

What had been done was to give Teku an initial state and load a key that had not yet been activated. Curious as to how it got into a state where it didn't track finalized epoch correctly and did not attest, from there.

```
consensus_1         | 11:40:40.130 INFO  - Slot Event  *** Slot: 517703, Block: 206396..9e1c, Epoch: 16178, Finalized checkpoint: 16176, Finalized root: 890e88..bbd4, Peers: 2

consensus_1         | 11:44:52.270 INFO  - Slot Event  *** Slot: 517724, Block: 8c56a5..010d, Epoch: 16178, Finalized checkpoint: 16176, Finalized root: 890e88..bbd4, Peers: 33
consensus_1         | 11:45:04.220 INFO  - Slot Event  *** Slot: 517725, Block: eafc19..2c5a, Epoch: 16178, Finalized checkpoint: 16176, Finalized root: 890e88..bbd4, Peers: 33
consensus_1         | 11:45:16.107 INFO  - Slot Event  *** Slot: 517726, Block: 3f94b8..ab66, Epoch: 16178, Finalized checkpoint: 16176, Finalized root: 890e88..bbd4, Peers: 33
consensus_1         | 11:45:28.301 INFO  - Slot Event  *** Slot: 517727, Block: 7d1acd..1987, Epoch: 16178, Finalized checkpoint: 16176, Finalized root: 890e88..bbd4, Peers: 32
consensus_1         | 11:45:36.022 INFO  - Epoch Event *** Epoch: 16179, Justified checkpoint: 16177, Finalized checkpoint: 16176, Finalized root: 890e88..bbd4
consensus_1         | 11:45:36.093 INFO  - Attestation performance: expected 0, produced 0, included 0 (0%), distance 0 / 0.00 / 0, correct target 0 (0%), correct head 0 (0%)
```

I suspect on the first attempt it actually started from an existing database so didn't load the initial state and was still syncing:
```
consensus_1         | 11:30:40.135 WARN  - Not loading specified initial state as chain data already exists.
```

and it was still syncing at the end of the quoted logs:
```
consensus_1         | 11:34:13.070 INFO  - Sync Event  *** Current slot: 517671, Head slot: 321695, Connected peers: 27
```

Note the head slot is still a fair way behind so it clearly started from some time well before the latest finalized epoch.


> Teku logs that it attested, but actually did not. 

In this case it did publish the attestation, but because attestations can be included up to an epoch later, the performance metrics always lag so the "Attestation performance" report is actually related to two epochs prior when the beacon node wasn't aware of any validators it was responsible for running.

I had restarted it at that point, it had been up for two days and had started from a fresh DB, and did get initial state, but never started attesting. The logs before restart are gone.

I can try and reproduce this and keep the logs that time.

Apologies for the delay in getting back to you on this one.  I'm not sure exactly what happened, but the logs are exactly what you should see for a node that's syncing.  The "Current slot" is based off of clock time so it's high but the finalized epoch only updates as blocks are imported and it's exactly in line with where the "Head slot" is up to.

We'd need the logs of the first run when the sync started to know why the initial state wasn't used.
Understood. This is likely a very specific set of circumstances. I’ll try to recreate.
I'm going to close this one as can't reproduce for now just to keep things neat, but please do reopen it if you find more info.
